dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Quick shots of a car speeding around  curves in a mountainous region. The  car jumps a bridge, hurtles into space,  crashes in a fireball. Followed by newsboys  hawking special editions, people on  streetcorners buying and reading newspapers  with a succession of banner headlines:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and finally "SEMPLE HEIR AS YET UNKNOWN"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Mac, the editor, at his desk, barking  into the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say listen, Corny, who do you think  you're talking to? If the Semple attorneys  don't know who the heir is, who does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on Corny, I've done you a lot  of favors. What do you say - who's getting  the Semple dough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Cornelius Cobb - a hardened ex-newspaperman,  customarily impatient, grouchy and nervous  - victim of the New York tempo. His  friends call him "Corny."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're asking the wrong guy, Mac. I'm  only a press agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PULLS BACK GRADUALLY TO REVEAL  a plush law office, leather chairs and  shelves of books. Arthur Cedar, attorney,  briskly enters scene and seats himself  at his desk. Cedar is in the neighborhood  of fifty - grey-templed - dignified  - sharp. Cobb is using the phone on  his desk. Cedar glances at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wants to know who the heir is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mac, I can't. Yeah, Mac. Sure,  but I ain't the attorneyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PULLS BACK FURTHER TO REVEAL  another attorney at one end of the desk,  reviewing a pile of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cedar is, and I haven't seen him  in two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Cedar, we've got to do something  about the newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in the newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's a great story. Somewhere in  this country a guy is walking into twenty  million bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. My first concern is to  locate the lucky man. When I do, it's  your job to keep the newspapers away  from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay with me as long as my weekly  stipend keeps coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PULLS BACK TO A FULL SHOT  as two men rush in with a flurry of  excitement. One of them is Anderson,  an obsequious employee of Cedar's. With  him is another lawyer, one of the Cedar  brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We located him, Mr. Cedar! We found  out where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the report: Longfellow Deeds,  single, 28, lives in Mandrake Falls,  Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better wire him right away, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do no such thing. I'm going there  myself. You're going with me too, Anderson  - and you too, Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes a button on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make three reservations on the first  train out to Mandrake Falls, Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pleasantly rural scene - with  just a handful of local characters scattered  about. At one end of the platform -  some mail - newspapers - and a few pieces  of freight are being loaded. Cedar,  Cobb and Anderson stand in front of  a welcome sign. The three obviously  are out of their element here - obviously  "City folks."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over their shoulders. We hear Cobb's  voice as he reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is the town he lives  in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Mr. Cedar. This is the town  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I dropped everything at the office  - I hope it's not a wild goose chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. We checked it thoroughly. He  lives here all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! I spy a native. Let's ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they cross  to a small, one-story old brick building,  covered with ivy. This is the ticket  and freight office combined. In front  of it is a very old man, a stoop-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shouldered rail agent with a face of  a million wrinkles - puttering around  some packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a package and disappears  into the building. Cedar and Cobb look  at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an excellent start. At least  we've broken the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man returns to his pile of packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, my friend, do you know a fellow  by the name of Longfellow Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Yes, indeedy. Everyone knows  Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a game he's playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man shows up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd like to get in touch with him.  It's very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deeds! Who do you think I'm talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes - Deeds. Fine fellow. Very democratic.  You won't have no trouble at all. Talk  to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whereupon the old man carries another  package inside. Cobb is properly exasperated  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we'd better try somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we won't! The next time that jumping  jack comes out, I'll straddle him while  you ask him your questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man emerges from the building  and looks up at them as if he's never  seen them before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6. TWO SHOT - COBB AND AGENT (FEATURING  COBB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs the old man as he turns to  head back into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember us? We're the fellows who were  here a minute ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Yes, indeedy. I never forget  a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns again - but Cobb holds him  by the arm and sets him down on a small  packing case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Pop, we've come all the way  from New York to look up a fellow by  the name of Deeds. It's important -  very important!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to get rough, neighbor.  All you got to do is ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then please pretend, for just one fleeting  moment, that I'm asking. Where does  he reside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb turns away in disgust. Anderson  steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow Deeds - where does he live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's what you want! Well, why  didn't you say so in the first place  instead of beating around the bush?  Those other fellows don't know what  they're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll take you there in my car.  If they'd only explained to me what  they wanted, there would be no trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves Cobb and Cedar staring after  him killingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little old lady, Mrs. Meredith, answers  a knock at the door. Cedar, Cobb and  Anderson stand there, with the old man  at their heels. Mrs. Meredith is a sweet,  soft-voiced, timid and fluttery little  creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, will you come in please, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - he's over to the park arranging  for the bazaar, so's to raise money  for the fire engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal, you shoulda knowed he was in the  park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knew it all the time. But these men  said they wanted to see the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't read their minds if they don't  say what they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb glares after him exasperatedly.  Mrs. Meredith turns to Cobb and Cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, please. Come in. Can I get  you a cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. Sure I couldn't get you a  glass of lemonade or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you. Are you related  to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'd like to find out something  about him. What does he do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Jim Mason own the Tallow Works.  But that's not where he makes his money.  He makes most of it from his poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness, yes. Longfellow's famous.  He writes all those things on postcards.  You know, for Christmas - and Easter  - and birthdays. Sit down, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches over to a desk and picks  one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's one - he got $25 for this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When you've nowhere to turn - and you're  filled with doubt -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you know that your mother's heart  cries out -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog enters, racing toward the door,  scratching at it and whining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and goes out, with  the dog racing ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suggest you break it to him gently.  He's liable to keel over from the shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Meredith re-appears. We hear her  voice as she comes through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been waiting a long while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm John Cedar - of the New York firm  of Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Cobb. He watches Longfellow  who is glancing at the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Budington must feel like an awful stranger,  hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's eyes pop at the nifty.[1]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cornelius Cobb and Mr. Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange greetings. Longfellow  gestures to chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow crosses to his tuba near  a chair. He takes a mouthpiece out of  his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New mouthpiece. Been waiting two weeks  for this. Kids keep swiping them all  the time. They use 'em for bean shooters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gentlemen going to stay for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow looks at them strangely and  sits down beside his tuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, are you the son of Dr. Joseph  and Mary Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, does the name of Martin W.  Semple mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. He's an uncle of mine, I think.  I never saw him, but my mother's name  was Semple, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he passed on. He was killed in  a motor accident in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was? Gee, that's too bad. If there's  anything I can do toВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he speaks, he has been adjusting  the tuba between his legs and now sucks  on the mouthpiece, preparatory to playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have good news for you, sir. Mr. Semple  left a large fortune when he died. He  left it all to you, Mr. Deeds. Deducting  the taxes, it amounts to something in  the neighborhood of $20,000,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lips are over the mouthpiece of  the tuba. His only reaction to the startling  news is to lift his eyes in Cedar's  direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about lunch? Are the gentlemen going  to stay - or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they're going to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got some fresh orange layer cake.  You know, with the thick stuff on the  top?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, they don't want to go to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Meredith leaves. Cobb and Cedar  have watched this by-play, open-mouthed,  and are now even more astounded to see  Longfellow blow into his tuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you didn't hear what I said,  Mr. Deeds! The whole Semple fortune  goes to you! $20,000,000!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I heard you all right. $20,000,000.  That's quite a lot, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it'll do in a pinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed. I wonder why he left me  all that money? I don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men sit around a table, having  lunch. By Longfellow's side is, as expected,  the tuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb here is an ex-newspaperman  associated with your uncle for many  years - as a sort of buffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You see, rich people need someone  to keep the crowds away. The world's  full of pests. Then there's the newspapers  to handle. One must know when to seek  publicity - and when to avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During Cedar's speech, Longfellow seems  to have been lost in his own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington. Funny,  I can't think of a rhyme for Budington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whenever I run across a funny  name, I always like to poke around for  a rhyme. Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There once was a man named Cobb,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who kept Semple away from the mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Came the turn of the tide

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now poor Cobb's out of a job!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a two weeks' notice to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotten the 'sackaroo' in many ways  - but never in rhyme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't mean that. I'm sure I'm  going to need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's different if it's just poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Meredith enters with coffee  which she pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a married man, Mr. Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's too fussy for that. That's  what's the matter with him. There are  lots of nice girls right here in Mandrake  Falls who're dying to be marriedВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pay any attention to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a lot of foolish notions -  about saving a lady in distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you keep out of this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saving a lady in distress, eh? Well,  I suppose we all have dreams like that  when we are young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, we'd better get started.  You'll have to pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to New York with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we've got any suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we could borrow a couple from  Mrs. Simpson. You know, she went to  Niagara Falls last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kind of nervous. I've never been  away from Mandrake Falls in my life.  Kind of like to see Grant's Tomb, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take a walk around town, meet  you at the train at four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mr. Deeds. You're one  of the richest men in the country. We'll  see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23. TWO SHOT - LONGFELLOW AND MRS. MEREDITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear what he said? You know how much  twenty million is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care how much it is. You sit  right there and eat your lunch. You  haven't touched a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow nibbles at some food, staring  into space thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole town is out. The band is playing  "He's a Jolly Good Fellow" - the crowd  sings. It's a festive occasion. A large,  awkwardly painted sign looms over everyone's  head. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They peer anxiously around, looking  for someone, when Cobb dashes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked everywhere. I even went to  his house. It's locked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably had a change of heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't very anxious to come in the  first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band has already begun and is now  in the midst of "For He's A Jolly Good  Fellow."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, as he looks off, a startled  expression comes into Cobb's eyes. He  grabs Cedar by the arm - who glances  in the direction he points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Longfellow, in his customary position,  blowing on his tuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar and Cobb stare, wide-eyed, as  the song is finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. is the train with Longfellow  standing on the observation platform,  clutching his tuba. On either side of  him is Cedar and Cobb. In the f.g. the  crowd yells its farewell. Several of  them stuff baskets of fruit into his  hands. The band plays "Auld Lang Syne."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Longfellow and Cobb's shoulders.  As the train begins pulling out. Longfellow  smiles wanly and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mrs. Meredith! Goodbye, Jim!  Bye, Buddy! Goodbye, everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, I've got a lot of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb looks up into Longfellow's face  - affected by the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is slumped in his seat, his  legs sprawled out, his eyes ceilingward  - in deep thought. Cobb sits across  from him. Cedar enters, hangs up his  coat, hat and cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Cedar exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry if I were you. Of course,  a large fortune like this entails a  great responsibility - but you'll have  a good deal of help. So don't worry.  Leave everything to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wasn't worried about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering where they're going  to get another tuba player for the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb has just finished taking a drink  and can't help but nearly spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 20th Century crossing the Harlem  River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the 20th Century going under the  street level on Park Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon which we read: "CEDAR, CEDAR &  BUDINGTON - ENTRANCE." CAMERA PULLS  BACK to take in Cedar, who opens the  door and walks through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Cedar as he strides across the  room - in business-like fashion. He  comes to a door marked "PRIVATE OFFICES."  He pushes this door opens and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, John. Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background is typical office  hub-bub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus of "Good Morning, Mr. Cedar!"  issues from the clerks. A secretary  looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Cedar - as he passes through the  room - arriving at a door marked "JOHN  CEDAR, PRIVATE." He goes through the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar breezes in and speaks to a secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for you in the other office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides across the room to still  another door marked "PRIVATE" and he  disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of associates sit around in  large leather chairs, as Cedar barges  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men come to life. Some rise - others  lean forward. Two of them are brothers  of Cedar - tall and athletic. The third  is a small, frightened-looking man.  He is Budington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got nothing to worry about. He's  as naive as a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get Mrs. Cedar on the phone,  please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smartest thing I ever did was to  make that trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, did you get the - uhВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Budington, I didn't get the Power  of Attorney. But don't worry, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked him last night what he was going  to do with the money, and what do you  suppose he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he guessed he'd give it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy must be a nit-wit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Budington hasn't enjoyed the joke -  his mind still on their problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, John, you had the right hunch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, if you don't mind my saying so  - we can't afford toВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Budington. We can't afford to  have the books investigated right now.  You must have said that a thousand times  already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if they fall into somebody  else's hands, why - uhВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it hasn't happened yet - has it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a half million dollars! My goodness,  where are we going to getВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop worrying! It was I who  got old man Semple to turn everything  over to us, wasn't it? And who got the  Power of Attorney from him ! All right,  and I'll get it again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it easy. Those books'll never  leave this office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Semple, a ne'er-do-well, prominent  for the pouches under his eyes and a  perpetual nose-twitch, is sprawled out  in a chair reading a newspaper. A nagging  wife walks around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A yokel! Nothing but a yokel! Your uncle  must have been mad to leave all that  money to him! You're as closely related  to him as he is, and what did you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She storms around the room. George merely  twitches his nose but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, what did you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop yelling. Can I help it if my uncle  didn't like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to be nice to him. Ten years  we've been waiting for that old man  to kick off. And then we were going  to be on Easy Street. Yeah - on Easy  Street!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up! It's too late now, and  you're a nuisance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just what I'm going to be - a  nuisance. I'm going to be a nuisance  until I get hold of some of that money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The editor stands in front of his desk.  Four of five reporters in front of him  - several photographers. In the b.g.,  leaning against the wall near the door,  apparently indifferent, is Babe Bennett.  The editor, Mac, is haranguing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's news! Every time he blows his nose,  it's news. A corn-fed bohunk like that  falling into the Semple fortune is hot  copy . . . But it's got to be personal.  It's got to have an angle. What does  he think about? How does it feel to  be a millionaire! Is he going to get  married! What does he think of New York!  Is he smart? Is he dumb? . . . A million  angles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a string in her hand which she  keeps flicking, trying to get a knot  into it - in the manner of cowboys with  a rope. Mac's voice continues over scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of them all, as Mac continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been here three days, and what  have you numbskulls brought in! Any  halfwit novice could have done better!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I talking too loud? Or annoying anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Corny Cobb. He's keeping him  under lock and key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb, Cobb! Never mind about Cobb. Use  what little brains you've got! Find  out something yourselves, you imbecilic  stupes! Now get out of here before I  really tell you what I think of you.  Come on, get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They scramble to their feet. One of  the reporters mumbles something as he  passes Mac on the way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? I said you had dirty plaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Babe is still flicking her string,  trying to get a knot. The reporters  file past her on their way out. Just  as the last one is approaching, she  succeeds in doing the trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too! Thought I could depend on you,  but you're getting as bad as the rest  of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs up a handful of papers and  starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's gotten into you, Babe? I remember  the time when you'd blast this town  wide open before you'd let Cobb get  away with a thing like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's not getting away with anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Babe - get me some stuff on  this guy, and you can haveВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a month's vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave four columns open on the front  page tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're talking, Babe. I'll keep  the whole front page open. What are  you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits. Mac's face lights up happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow stands awkwardly between  two tailors - who chalk and pin a suit  on him. After a few seconds of silence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first time I ever had a suit  made on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tailors smile accommodatingly as  CAMERA PULLS BACK and we discover that  both Cedar and Cobb are present. Cobb  is slumped in a chair, and Cedar is  carefully putting some papers away in  a portfolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's merely a suggestion. I don't wish  to press the point, Mr. Deeds, but if  you'll give me your Power of Attorney  we'll take care of everything. It'll  save you a lot of petty annoyances.  Every shark in town will be trying to  sell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, there've been a lot of them  around here already. Strangest kind  of people. Salesmen - politicians -  moochers - all want something. I haven't  had a minute to myself. Haven't seen  Grant's Tomb yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, your uncle didn't bother  with that sort of thing. He left everything  to us. He traveled most of the time,  and enjoyed himself. You should do the  same thing, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides wanting to be my lawyer, you  also want to handle my investments too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, outside of your regular fee, how  much extra will it cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That involves a lot of extra work, doesn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but that's an added service a firm  like Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington  usually donates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Budington. Funny, I can't think of a  rhyme for Budington yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a butler stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentlemen from the opera are still  waiting in the board room, sir. They're  getting a trifle impatient, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are? I forgot all about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think they want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your uncle was Chairman of the  Board of Directors. They probably expect  you to carry on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell those mugs to keep their shirts  on, that you'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, did you send that telegram to Jim  Mason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim Mason? Oh, yeah. Yeah. No, I didn't  send it. I've got it written out, though.  Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Arthur's been with the Tallow Works  too long. STOP. Don't think we should  fire him. Longfellow."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Send it right away. I don't want  him to fire Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Sure. We don't want to fire  Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the last baby my father delivered,  Arthur was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you ought to give this matter  some thought, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, about the Power of Attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb has stalled long enough to hear  Longfellow's decision before he goes  out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give it a lot of thought. There  was a fellow named Winslow here a little  while ago, wanted to handle my affairs  for nothing too. It puzzles me why these  people all want to work for nothing.  It isn't natural. So I guess I'd better  think about it some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow, Cedar and the two tailors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to an awful lot of work to keep  a fellow warm, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mr. Hallor to see you sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lawyer representing some woman with  a claim against the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to see me at my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if he has a claim, we'd better  see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's capable of causing you a lot of  trouble, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can he make any trouble for me?  I haven't done anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler reappears, followed by Hallor.  The minute he appears, Cedar speaks  up belligerently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I told you to take up this  matter with me, Hallor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little tired of being pushed around  by you, Mr. Cedar - I don't care how  important you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, I represent Mrs. Semple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Your uncle's common-law wife. She  has a legal claim on the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll let the courts decide what her  legal position is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't dare go into court with  a case like this - and you know it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Longfellow, who has listened  to them studyingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leave it to you, Mr. Deeds. Can you  conceive of any court not being in sympathy  with any woman who gave up the best  years of her life for an old man like  your uncle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of wife did you say she was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Common-law wife. On top of that, there's  a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's awful. The poor woman should  be taken care of immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to see you're willing to be  reasonable, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she was his wife, she should have  all the money. That's only fair. I don't  want a penny of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yanks his trousers off and hands  them to the tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tailors exit, Cobb returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better get right down there. That  opera mob is about to break into the  Mad Song from "Lucia."[2]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't want to keep them waiting  any longer. They're important people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd go along with me, Cobb.  They're all strangers to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about it, Mr. Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll excuse me, won't you? I'll be  right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Longfellow and Cobb come out and  start down corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I'm busy. Did the opera people  always come here for their meetings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do mice go where there's cheese?[3]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of eight distinguished-looking  men sit around a long table, awaiting  Longfellow's arrival. At the head of  the table is a Mr. Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I'm led to believe, the young  man's quite childish. I don't think  we'll have any difficulty in getting  him to put up the entire amount. After  all, it's only a matter of $180,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drop in the bucket for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, gentlemen, we're really very  fortunate the young man is so sympathetic  toward music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays the tuba in the town band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a shuffle of preparation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Longfellow and Cobb present. Longfellow  looks around, completely awed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, gentlemen, the first order of business  will be the election of a new Chairman  of the Board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a sentimental gesture toward the  best friend opera ever had, the late  Mr. Semple, I think it only fitting  that his nephew, Mr. Longfellow Deeds,  should be made our next Chairman. I  therefore nominate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Yes, of course - you've just been  elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Longfellow is led to the president's  chair. Douglas sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the next order of business is the  reading of the Secretary's minutes .  . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they can be dispensed with.  We're ready now for the reading of the  Treasurer's report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right! Now, gentlemen, the next  business will beВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What does the Chairman  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, the Chairman presides at the meetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. If you don't  mind, I'm rather interested in the Treasurer's  report. I'd like to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an uncomfortable shuffle. For  a few minutes, no one speaks. From the  rear, a tall man rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The treasurer reports a deficit of $180,000  for the current year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deficit! You mean we've lost that  much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not  conducted for profit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't? What is it conducted for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We own an opera house, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you charge. I mean, you sell tickets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible. The opera has never  paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, we must give the wrong kind  of shows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb smiles. The directors are stumped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrong kind! There isn't any wrong  or right kind. Opera is opera!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it is. But I personally wouldn't  care to be head of a business that kept  losing money. That wouldn't be common  sense. Incidentally, where is the $180,000  coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we were rather expecting it to  come from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, gentlemen, there's nothing  natural about that .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is suddenly startled. His ears prick  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all stare at Longfellow. Over scene  comes the low wailing cry of a siren,  which increases in volume as it gets  closer to the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes to the window and peers out.  The others stare unbelievably. The shriek  of the siren finally dies down. Longfellow  turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he goes back to his seat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expect we're going to have one like  that in Mandrake Falls pretty soon В–  with a siren, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause while he gets seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not  conducted like any ordinary business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it just isn't a business, that's  all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it isn't to you, but it  certainly is a business to me, if I  have to make up a loss of $180,000.  If it's losing that much money, there  must be something wrong. Maybe you charge  too much. Maybe you're selling bad merchandise.  Maybe lots of things. I don't know.  You see, I expect to do a lot of good  with that money. And I can't afford  to put it into anything that I don't  look into. That's my decision for the  time being, gentlemen. Goodbye, and  thank you for making me Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits, followed by Cobb, whose eyes  shriek his admiration. The directors  watch them leave, flabbergasted. Cobb's  head reappears in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, you'll find the smelling  salts in the medicine chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears. The Board of Directors  stare in dumb stupefaction at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Longfellow enters. Hallor and Cedar  rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting so long. Those  opera people are funny. They wanted  me to put up $180,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, I turned them down, naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean - about my client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - we'll have to do something about  the common wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow's valet, Walter, enters and  holds up a full dress suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, that's a monkey suit![5] Do you  want people to laugh at me? I never  wore one of those things in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wants me to wear a monkey suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar and Hallor smile accommodatingly.  Walter hands him a pair of trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Longfellow starts getting into the  trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, we don't want to appear greedy,  Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we don't want to appear greedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has gotten down on his knees  and holds the ends of the pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up from there. I don't want anybody  holding the ends of my pants. Get up  from there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine that - holding the ends of my  pants!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallor smiles feebly - his impatience  growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Semple is entitled by law to one-third  of the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't ever get down on your knees  again, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Semple is entitled to one-third  of the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we didn't expect that much. I'm  sure I can get her to settle quietly  for one million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's any talk of settlement, Hallor,  take it up with me at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Don't you go to his office.  There's only one place you're going,  and that's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making a mistake, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, I'm not. I don't like your face.  Besides, there's something fishy about  a person who would settle for a million  dollars when they can get seven million.  I'm surprised that Mr. Cedar, who's  supposed to be a smart man, couldn't  see through that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow crosses to bell cord and  pulls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one nice thing about being rich  - you ring a bell and things happen.  When the servant comes in, Mr. Hallor,  I'm going to ask him to show you to  the door. Many people don't know where  it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No use in getting tough. That'll get  you nowhere, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a butler enters, Longfellow turns  to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you show Mr. Hallor to the front  door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hallor gets to it. Longfellow grabs  him by the shirt front and half lifts  him off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And listen, there isn't any wife - there  aren't any letters - and I think you're  a crook. So you better watch your step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves Hallor violently and he stumbles  out of scene. Cobb enters to Longfellow,  his hand extended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hold out on you any longer.  Lamb bites wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar has been most uncomfortable through  the scene, but now suavely assumes an  admiring attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hold out any longer either,  Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being an attorney for you will be a  very simple affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not my attorney yet, Mr. Cedar.  Not till I find out what's on your mind.  Suppose you get the books straightened  out quick so I can have a look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, if you wish. But you  must be prepared. This sort of thing  will be daily routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it becomes annoying, you let me know.  Goodbye, Mr. Deeds. Goodbye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow shakes his hand. Cedar exits.  Longfellow stares after him disgustedly,  wiping his hands with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has entered and holds up a coat  for Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how about tonight? What would  you like in the way of entertainment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your uncle had a weakness for dark ones,  tall and stately. How would you like  yours? Dark or fair, tall or short,  fat or thin, tough or tender?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name your poison and I'll supply it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time, Cobb. Some other time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your blood begins to boil, yell  out. I'll be seeing you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cobb exits. Longfellow turns to Walter,  the valet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He talks about women as if they were  cattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every man to his taste, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Walter, are all those stories  I hear about my uncle true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, he sometimes had as many  as twenty in the house at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty! What did he do with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was something I was never able  to find out, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow, exiting his bedroom, wearing  a coat and hat. He comes to the top  of a grand staircase, looks around slyly  and sees that no one is watching. He  slides down the bannister and touches  the statue at the bottom for good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the door. When he gets  there he finds his way barred by two  husky-looking mugs. He looks up surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why yes. Isn't that all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't ever want to go out without  telling us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Mr. Cobb said stick to your tail  no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very nice of Mr. Cobb - but I  don't want anybody sticking to my tail  no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We gotta get you up in the  morning - and we gotta put you to bed  at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only it's all right. No matter what  we see - we don't see nuttin', see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow glances around the room thoughtfully,  then continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, will you do something for me before  we go out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first bodyguard eagerly takes out  a pistol. The second bodyguard slaps  it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a trunk in that room. Will you  get it out for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two bodyguards accommodatingly enter  a closet. The moment they are gone,  Longfellow closes the door calmly and  turns the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey! We're your bodyguards. You  can't do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow comes out, glances over the  horizon. The air is filled with a slight  drizzle and he sighs happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe and two photographers, Bob and  Frank, are huddled conspiratorially  in the back seat of a taxi cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is. Yep, that's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the cameras ready and follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. Follow me and grab whatever  you can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's going to be the same  old thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you that dame's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his angle. Out of the shadows a  girl comes into view and staggers forward.  She reaches a tree and clutches it weakly.  Then her strength failing, she crumples  to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow's eyes widen in apprehension  as he starts forward - CAMERA FOLLOWING  HIM. He reaches the girl and bending  down, lifts her head. We see it is Babe  Bennett. Her eyes are closed, apparently  in a dead faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80. CLOSE SHOT - LONGFELLOW AND BABE  - LOW ANGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow studies her face for a moment,  then starts to lift her. As he does  so, her eyes open and she looks up at  him, feigning bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She struggles to get to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is my house. I'd like toВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, really - I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I walked too much. I've  been looking for a job all day. I found  one, too. I start tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been awfully kind. Thank you  very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leaves him, Longfellow watches  her, full of sympathy. She takes a few  steps and, again feigning weakness,  falls against the iron fence, clutching  it. Longfellow rushes to her assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, stupe! Follow that cab they just  got into, will you? Hurry up! Step on  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A corner table, surrounded by ferns,  at which Longfellow and Babe sit. She's  still eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, it tastes so good. Mr. Deeds, I  don't know how I can ever thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I've told you almost everything  there is to tell. My folks live in a  small town near Hartford. I'm down here  alone trying to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm really just a nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow spots a strolling violinist.  He furtively beckons the fellow over.  The musician leans into them with romantic  strains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the musician finishes and strolls  away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was so lovely. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a lady in distress, weren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a waiter enters the scene and begins  removing dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiter! Has anybody come in yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure and point 'em out to me, won't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a writer myself, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter throws Longfellow a sidelong  glance of complete boredom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86. CLOSE TWO SHOT - BABE AND LONGFELLOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been having quite an exciting  time here, haven't you? All those meetings  and business deals and society people  - haven't you been having fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until I met you. I like talking to you,  thoughВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine my finding you right on my doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over at that big round table. The one  that looks like a poodle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow stares off scene - his eyes  full of worship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their angle, to show people at  a table, engaged in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Longfellow's table. He stares off  at them, awed. Babe watches his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of five men, drinking - as the  waiter enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon. Longfellow Deeds, who just inherited  the Semple fortune, wants to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I read about him. He writes  poetry on postcards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's invite him over. Might get a couple  of laughs. Getting rather dull around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At which they are all seated now. Babe  sits next to Longfellow, who is the  center of attraction. Brookfield is  just finishing introductions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henaberry, Mr. Morrow, Bill - this is  Mr. Deeds and his fiancГ©e from Mandrake  Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of you to ask us to come and sit  with you. Back home we never get a chance  to meet famous people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds is a distinguished poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a poet. Have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - I don't want it, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you must drink! All poets drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us, Mr. Deeds. How do you go about  writing your poems? We craftsmen are  very interested in one another's methods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you have to wait for an inspiration,  or do you just dash it off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Morrow, over there, for instance,  just dashes them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's what my publishers have  been complaining about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93. CLOSE SHOT GROUP - BABE AND LONGFELLOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe glances up at Longfellow, to see  if he's aware that he is being laughed  at. But he apparently isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your readers don't complain, Mr. Morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I write mine on order. The people  I work for just tell me what they want  and then I go to work and write it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Have you any peculiar characteristics  when you are creating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been playing the harmonica for  forty years - didn't do me a bit of  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have one in your pocket,  would you, Mr. Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, a postcard - with one of your poems  on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is beginning to sense he  is being kidded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me you don't carry  a pocketful around with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad! I was hoping you'd autograph  one for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they keep on. Longfellow has his  eyes levelled on each speaker in turn,  obviously cognizant of their ill-concealed  jibes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, boys. Perhaps Mr. Deeds  would recite one for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a very good idea. Nothing like  a poet reciting his own stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a Mother's Day poem, Mr. Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! Give us one that wrings the  great American heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe has been watching Longfellow, interested.  Now, when their voices die down - and  they wait expectantly - he speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I get the idea. I guess I know  why I was invited here. To make fun  of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what if I am? What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy to make fun of somebody if  you don't care how much you hurt 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think your poems are swell, Mr. Brookfield,  but I'm disappointed in you. I know  I must look funny to you, but maybe  if you went to Mandrake Falls you'd  look just as funny to us . Only nobody  would laugh at you and make you feel  ridiculous - 'cause that wouldn't be  good manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess maybe it is comical to write  poems for postcards, but a lot of people  think they're good. Anyway, it's the  best I can do. So if you'll excuse me,  we'll be leaving. I guess I found out  that all famous people - aren't big  people . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group watches him silently as he  leaves the table accompanied by Babe.  For a moment they are nonplussed - then  they break into raucous laughter - all  but Morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Longfellow and Babe as they take  several steps. Then he abruptly stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just one thing more. If it weren't  for Miss Dawson being here with me,  I'd probably bump your heads together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow stares at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I guess maybe I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts back toward the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protectively, Brookfield and Henaberry  rise from their chairs. But they are  too late, for Longfellow clips Brookfield  on the chin first with his left fist  - and with his right catches Henaberry  on the jaw. The punches are almost simultaneous.  The surprise attack catches the men  off-guard and they fall backward. A  waiter rushes forward to escort Longfellow  and Babe out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrow, who never budged from his chair,  and who has watched Longfellow with  great admiration, now rises to catch  up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Morrow catches up to Longfellow and  Babe, who are on their way out. The  waiter is shooing people away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrow barges forward. Longfellow and  Babe turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say fellow, you neglected me - and I  feel very put out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, sock it right there, will you?  Lay one right on the button,[6] but  sock it hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. I got it off my chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The difference between them and me is  I know when I've been a skunk. You take  me to the nearest news-stand and I'll  eat a pack of your postcards raw. Raw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow and Babe smile. As Morrow  continues to speak, he sways drunkenly  and would fall over backwards a couple  of times in midsentence if the alert  Longfellow didn't have a clutch on his  collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what a magnificent deflation of  smugness. Pal, you've added ten years  to my life! A poet with a straight left  and a right hook - delicious! Delicious!  You're my guest from now on - forever  and a day - even unto eternity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but Miss Dawson and I are going  out to see the sights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, fine. Swell, You just showed me  a sight lovely to behold, and I'd like  to reciprocate. Listen, you hop aboard  my magic carpetВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Longfellow catches him before he falls  backward in his enthusiasm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—thanks - and I'll show you sights that  you've never seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd kind of like to see Grant's Tomb  - and the Statue of Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'll not only see those, but  before the evening's half through, you'll  be leaning against the Leaning Tower  of Pisa - you'll mount Mt. Everest.  I'll show you the Pyramids and all the  little Pyramiddes, leaping from sphinx  to sphinx. Pal, how would you like to  go on a real, old-fashioned binge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I mean the real McCoy. Listen,  you play saloon with me, and I'll introduce  you to every wit, every nit-wit, and  every half-wit in New York. We'll go  on a twister that'll make Omar the soused  philosopher of Persia[7] look like an  anemic on a goat's milk diet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow saves him - once again -  from crashing over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fun? Say, listen, I'll take you on a  bender that will live in your memory  as a thing of beauty and joy forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits from the scene. CAMERA FOLLOWING  HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Tempora! Oh, Moeraes! Oh, Bacchus![8]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bumps into a woman, who glares at  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess if we go with him, we'll see  things, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at his face, amazed at  his innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac is reading the story, eyes sparkling.  Babe is sprawled in a chair, doing tricks  with a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "'I play the tuba to help me think.'  This is one of the many startling statements  made by Longfellow Deeds - New York's  new Cinderella Man - who went out last  night to prove that his uncle, the late  M.W. Semple - from whom he inherited  $20,000,000 - was a rank amateur in  the art of 'standing the town on its  cauliflower ear' . . . "[9]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinderella Man! That's sensational,  Babe! Sensational!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took some high-powered acting, believe  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the world's sweetest ingenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he really that big a sap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the original. There are no carbon  copies of that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinderella Man! Babe, you stuck a tag  on that hick that'll stick to him the  rest of his life. Can you imagine Cobb's  face when he reads this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we could sell tickets, we'd make  a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She covers the coin with palm of other  hand, and the coin disappears. But Mac  is too excited to pay any attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "At two o'clock this morning, Mr. Deeds  tied up traffic while he fed a bagful  of doughnuts to a horse. When asked  why he was doing it, he replied: 'I  just wanted to see how many doughnuts  this horse would eat before he'd ask  for a cup of coffee.'"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I had to duck to get the  story out. He was so far along he never  even missed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When're you going to see him again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my lunch hour. I'm a stenographer,  you know. Mary Dawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a genius, Babe - a genius!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I even moved into Mabel Dawson's apartment  - in case old snoopy Cobb might start  looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Good! Stay there. Don't show your  face down here. I'll tell everybody  you're on your vacation. They'll never  know where the stories are coming from.  Stick close to him, Babe - you can get  an exclusive story out of him every  day for a month. We'll have the other  papers crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No. Our deal was for a month's  vacation - with pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get it, Babe. You'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter leans over the bed violently,  shaking Longfellow, who is lost in drunken  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds - Mr. Deeds, sir - you really  must get up. It's late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll permit me to say so, sir,  you were out on quite a bender last  night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow opens one eye - and then  the other, blinking. As consciousness  returns to him, he glances around the  room as if to get his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bender? You're wrong, Walter. We started  out to a binge but we never got to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter offers him a drink on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. It makes the head feel smaller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow takes it and downs it in  one swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Dawson, sir? No, sir. No Miss Dawson  has called, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a lady in distress. She wouldn't  let me help her. Got a lot of pride.  I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better call her up and apologize.  I don't remember taking her home last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd venture to say, sir, you don't remember  much of anything that happened last  night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? I remember everything!  Hand me my pants - I wrote her phone  number on a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow looks up slowly. Walter goes  on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came home last night - without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, you came home without  any clothes. You were in your - uh -  shorts. Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be silly, Walter. I couldn't  walk around in the streets without any  clothes. I'd be arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the two policemГ©n said,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones who brought you home, sir.  They said you and another gentleman  kept walking up and down the streets,  shouting: "Back to nature! Clothes are  a blight on civilization! Back to nature!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow watches his face, fascinated.  Slowly it is all coming back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Walter, if a man named Morrow  calls up, tell him I'm not in. He may  be a great author, but I think he's  crazy. The man's crazy, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. By the way, did youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow slowly swings out of bed  into a sitting position. Walter kneels  to put on Longfellow's slippers. Longfellow  balks, points, silently reminding Walter  that he has broken his promise not to  kneel down in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how'll I put on the slipper, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow's expression begs no disagreement.  Walter stands, fumbling with the shoes  from a stooped posture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I beg pardon, sir, but did  you ever find what you were looking  for, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kept searching me last night, sir.  Going through my pockets. You said you  were looking for a rhyme for Budington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better bring me some coffee, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I beg pardon. A telegram came for  you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you some black coffee, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Walter's exit. Longfellow  quickly opens the telegram. His face  clouds. At this moment, Cobb comes bursting  into the room - a newspaper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see all this stuff in the papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the shipping clerk at the Tallow  Works. Wants a $2 raise - or he'll quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I care about Arthur! Did you  see this stuff in the paper? How'd it  get in there? What'd you do last night?  Who were you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flings the paper on the bed. Longfellow  glances at it, and his face clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what'd you do to those bodyguards?  They quit this morning. Said you locked  them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they insisted on following me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think bodyguards are for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they mean by this - "Cinderella  Man!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow has his eyes glued on the  paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember. "Cinderella Man!"  What do they mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd call you anything if you gave  them half a chance. They've got you  down as a sap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll go down and punch this  editor on the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't! Get this clear: Socking  people is no solution for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not editors. Take my word for it. Not  editors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're going to poke fun at me,  I'm going toВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Listen, Longfellow. You've got  brains, kid. You'll get along swell  if you'll only curb your homicidal instincts  - and keep your trap shut. Don't talk  to anybody! These newshounds are out  gunning for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my job. I'll take care of that.  I'll keep that stuff out of the papers  - if you'll help me. But I can't do  anything if you go around talking to  people. Will you promise me to be careful  from now on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess I'll have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you feel the building rock, it'll  be me blasting into this editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. During the scene Walter has  entered with a tray, which he has adjusted  on Longfellow's knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's right. I mustn't talk to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Dawson on the phone, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll talk to her. Give me the  phone, quick. She's the only one I'm  going to talk to from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the butler scurries around for the  phone,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. TOP OF FIFTH AVENUE BUS - NIGHT  - (PROCESS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow looks around, absorbed. Babe  watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awfully nice of you to show me  around like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aquarium was swell. If I lived in  New York, I'd go there every day. I'll  bet you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like to - but I have a job  to think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Directly behind the bus. A man's head  is stuck out of taxi window. We recognize  it as one of the photographers, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, flap-ears![11] You better keep  following that bus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two photographers, with their equipment.  They keep their eyes glued on the bus  in front. They return to their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't look as though we're gonna  get any pictures tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe ought to get him drunk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, has anything exciting been happening  lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. What's happening about the opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that - well, we had another meeting.  I told them I'd go on being Chairman  ifВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told 'em I'd play along with them  if they lowered their prices - and cut  down expenses - and broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. They said I was crazy. Said  I wanted to run it like a grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always wear your hair like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, two girls pass by, chattering.  One girl has a paper open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it a scream - "Cinderella Man!"  The dope!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to get my hooks into that guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Somebody's probably taking  him for plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are gone. Longfellow glares after  them. Babe is afraid to look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they were men, I'd knock their heads  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe is silent. Longfellow watches her  for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like about you. You think  about a man's feelings. I'd like to  go down to that newspaper and punch  the fellow in the nose that's writing  that stuffВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—"Cinderella Man!" I guess pretty soon  everybody will be calling me "Cinderella  Man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe has had an uncomfortable time of  it - and quickly changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to walk the rest of the  way? It's so nice out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps up from her seat, and Longfellow  follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wise guys. He's getting off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sets off a mad scramble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129. MED. CLOSE SHOT - LONGFELLOW AND  BABE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands across the street from Grant's  Tomb, looking solemn. His eyes moist.  She is unaware of his emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, don't you want to see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 131. MED. CLOSE SHOT - LONGFELLOW AND  BABE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. Grant's Tomb. I hope  you're not disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To most people, it's an awful letdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, to most people it's a washout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on what they see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, I see a small Ohio farm boy  becoming a great soldier. I see thousands  of marching men. I see General Lee with  a broken heart, surrendering, and I  can see the beginning of a new nation,  like Abraham Lincoln said. And I can  see that Ohio boy being inaugurated  as PresidentВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things like that can only happen in  a country like America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To intercut with above speech. During  his recital, she watches his face, fascinated.  Her impulse is to laugh, but she finds  that she can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overcome - he almost chokes on his  final words)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Hopper. Mr. Cedar won't answer  his phone. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what's going on in the boss's office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search me. The three 'Cs' and little  'B' have been in there for over an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar paces the floor. His brothers  look worried. Budington is enthroned  at Cedar's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be critical, John, but  here it isВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. A week's gone by and we  haven't got the Power of Attorney yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what I said. I can't strangle  him, can I!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous for us to have to worry  about a boy like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these articles about him! "Cinderella  Man!" Why, he's carrying on like an  idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what I was saying to my wife  when thisВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares what you were saying to your  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment's awkward silence.  The silence is broken by the buzzing  of the dictograph. Cedar crosses to  it and snaps the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As secretary's voice comes over dictograph:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Semple are still waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it. Let them wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those people have been in to see me  every day this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
