dialogues.text: They keep insisting they should have  some nuisance value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say if it hadn't been for Deeds,  they'd have gotten all the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they have! Maybe they have! Maybe  they have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Semple, please. How do  you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others all stand around - as the  Semples enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138. MED. CLOSE SHOT - CEDAR AND THE  SEMPLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry to have kept you waiting.  How are you, sir? I don't know what  my secretary could

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: have been thinking to keep you waiting  this long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you bring the chairs? Quickly.  Will you have a cigar, Mr. Semple?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semple takes the cigar - rather flabbergasted  at all the sudden attention showered  upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. ROOF OF TALL BUILDING - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From over their shoulders, looking down  on the lights and teeming activity of  Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can almost spit on it, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does try. The wind blows it back  on him. She laughs, takes out a handkerchief  and wipes it off his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't say anything right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're worried about those articles  they're writing about you, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worrying any more. I suppose  they'll go on writing them till they  get tired. You don't believe all that  stuff, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guilty look spreads over Babe's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they just do it to sell the newspapers,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess so. What puzzles me is  why people seem to get so much pleasure  out of hurting each other. Why don't  they try liking each other once in a  while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Anyway, there aren't any photographers  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Frank, sneaking around in the  bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you said something to me when  you first met me that I've thought about  a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I was a lady in distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a - are you - uh - engaged  or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corners of her mouth go up in sympathetic  amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't go out with girls very much,  do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have met a lot of swell society  girls since you've been here. Don't  you like them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't met anybody here that I like,  particularly. They all seem to have  the St. Vitus Dance.[12]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People here are funny. They work so  hard at living - they forget how to  live

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night, after I left you, I was  walking along and looking at the tall  buildings and I got to thinking about  what Thoreau said. They created a lot  of grand palaces here - but they forgot  to create the noblemen to put in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Babe. She stares at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from a small town too, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably as small as Mandrake Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh! What do you know about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe leans her head back in a reminiscent  mood. We get a feeling that, for the  moment, she has forgotten she is Babe  Bennett, out on a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it's a beautiful little town, too.  A row of poplar trees right along Main  Street. Always smelled as if it just  had a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've often thought about going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I used to have a lot of fun  there when I was a little girl. I used  to love to go fishing with my father.  That's funny. He was a lot like you,  my father was. Talked like you, too.  Sometimes he'd let me hold the line  while he smoked - and we'd just sit  there for hours. And after awhile, for  no reason, I'd go over and kiss him  and sit in his lap. He never said very  much but once I remember him saying:  "No matter what happens, honey, don't  complain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sounds like a person worth while  knowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause while Longfellow watches  her, and she is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He played in the town band, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did? I play the tubaВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drums. He taught me to play some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I can do "Swanee River." Would  you like to hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up a couple of branches. With  the two sticks she drums on the bench  seat - and sings "Swanee River."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she is finished, though clearly  delighted, he shows her a long face  of mock-disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I suppose you could do better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Humoresque"? I'll bet you don't even  know how it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Look! You sing it over again,  and I'll do "Humoresque" with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts again, and he sings "Humoresque"  in counterpoint to her drumming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait with their camera. When they  hear the singing, they look up, and  then at each other in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if they'd want to make it a  quartet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow and Babe. They are having  a grand time with their singing. A policeman  saunters into the scene and stands watching  them for a few seconds, without their  being conscious of his presence. He  smiles, shakes his head and passes on  out of scene. Over the shot we hear  the low moan of a siren in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the climax of their song  - and laugh joyously. At this moment,  the shrieking of the siren is nearer  and louder. Longfellow looks up quickly.  Excited, he jumps up and runs toward  street. Babe looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire engine! Fire engine! I want to  see how they do it. Wait for me, will  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151. CLOSE SHOT - BOB AND FRANK BEHIND  BUSHES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like the evening is not going  to be wasted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dash by the policeman, who looks  up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the fire engine slows down - and  people are beginning to gather. We see  Longfellow running toward the truck  and hopping aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Deeds - fire volunteer - Mandrake  Falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Cap! Boys, meet the Captain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Frank running with their cameras  toward Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM OF MABEL DAWSON'S STUDIO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of typewriter carriage. It contains  a paper upon which the following is  typed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Longfellow Deeds, 'The Cinderella Man,'  last night threw a 'defy' into the teeth  of the New York Fire Department, that  when it comes to extinguishing conflagrations  - they had better look to their laurelsВ—"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK and we find Babe,  staring at the sheet of paper in front  of her. Her eyes have a distant look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several feet away from her Mabel Dawson  stands in front of an easel, working  silently on a painting. She dabs at  it and turning, pauses a moment to watch  Babe, who at the moment rests her forehead  on the typewriter carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe is too much absorbed to hear this.  Getting no response, Mabel turns and  studies her for a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Babe? Something's eating  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My unfailing instinct tells me something's  gone wrong with the stew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She again resumes her typing. Mabel  crosses to her and looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't gotten very far, have you?  That's where you were an hour ago. Come  on, let's knock off and go down to Joe's.  The gang's waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't write it, Mabel! I don't know  what's the matter with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe lights a cigarette. Mabel studies  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I think I can tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone bell rings. Mabel picks it  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's here. Who wants her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Yes, just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him - whatcha-ma-call-him - the  "Cinderella Man." The "Cinderella Man"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who lies dressed in bed, phone in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't sleep. Kinda wanted to talk  to you. Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - not at all. I couldn't sleep either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to thank you again for going  out with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Well, I don't know what I'd do  without you. You've made up for all  the fakes that I've met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's very nice. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I've been doing since  I got home? Been working on a poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it's kinda hard for me to  say things - so I write 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to read it some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She listens for a moment, apparently  moved by his sweetness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll have it finished next time  I see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, and lies back - enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel, that guy's either the dumbest,  the stupidest, the most imbecilic idiot  in the world - or he's the grandest  thing alive. I can't make him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why do we have to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You started out to be a successful newspaper  woman, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a guy that's wholesome and fresh.  To us he looks like a freak. You know  what he told me tonight? He said when  he gets married he wants to carry his  bride over the threshold in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he? Yeah, I thought so, too. I tried  to laugh, but I couldn't. It stuck in  my throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, cut it out, will you? You'll get  me thinking about Charlie again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got goodness, Mabel. Do you know  what that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - of course you don't. We've forgotten.  We're too busy being smart-alecks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too busy in a crazy competition for  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be put on paying basis - or else  - says post-card poet."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Launch Deeds on Social Career"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is in bed in his pajamas,  playing the tuba. Walter enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg pardon, sir. I beg pardon, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow stops, looking daggers at  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Pomponi is on the telephone,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Pomponi. She says everything  is all set for the reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by coming in here when  I'm playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evil finger's on you. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter hurries out. Longfellow jumps  up and chases him down the grand staircase.  Longfellow stops at the top of the stairs,  struck by an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing Walter at the bottom of the  stairs and Longfellow at the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter halts. Longfellow gives a shout  from the top of the stairs. There is  a discernible echo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow gives another shout. There  is another echo. He tries it again -  louder. Another echo. It is all very  satisfactory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gives a bird-like hoot. There  is an echo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter gives a louder hoot. And louder.  Each time, an echo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A butler in a bathrobe emerges to see  what all the hullabaloo is about. Longfellow  spots him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the butler clearly relishes the  opportunity. He gives a little high-pitched  squeak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler tries it again - much better.  Another man-servant has emerged. Longfellow  points to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man-servant tries it - very raspy,  another tone altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A symphony of hoots, shrieks, barks  and echoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The household staff do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let that be a lesson to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, Longfellow spins on his heel  and returns to his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause. The butler takes command  of the other two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to your room, both of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and the man-servant hasten to  exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler waits until nobody is looking,  then gives one, final hoot. He murmurs  to himself with satisfaction as he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Limousines arriving - from which guests  emerge - in full evening dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Pomponi greets a group of guests.  Ad-lib chatter is heard. From inside  music emanates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So good of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet of you to ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just dying to see the "Cinderella  Man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES SWIFTLY among groups of  people picking out vignettes of conversation.  Longfellow is the hot topic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A husband and a wife whispering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if he heard you, he wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man and a woman gossiping:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear he still believes in Santa Claus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he be Santa Claus? That's what  I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another man holding forth to two elegantly-dressed  women:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you all got your slippers ready  for the "Cinderella Man"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With $20,000,000, he doesn't have to  have looks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't have it long with that Pomponi  woman hanging around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two women in evening dress twittering  like birds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, I hear he can't think unless  he plays his tuba!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe is listlessly packing her few things  in a small handbag. She slowly and meticulously  folds a silken undergarment, wrapping  it in tissue. Her eyes have a distant  look. Mabel watches her, concerned.  There is a long pause before either  of them speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just couldn't stand seeing him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll I tell him if he calls up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I had to leave suddenly. I  got a job in China - some place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're acting like a school girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can I do? Keeping this up  is no good. He's bound to find out sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I can save him that .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are suddenly startled by the boisterous  entrance of Bob and Frank, whose voices  are heard as they barge in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe, not wishing to explain to them,  hides her bag - and follows Mabel to  greet them in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys cross to a table and drop their  cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, where is everybody? Come on, Babe  - the artillery's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel enters. Babe stands in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's those two sore spots again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda been down to the office  today, Babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Mac threw Cobb out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one little drink - and then we're  ready to shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. No, you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you had a date with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's off. He's having a party at his  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what's the matter with her now  !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't know if I drew you a diagram.  Now, run along and peddle your little  tin-types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Throwing us out of here's  getting to be a regular habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. They all  look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mabel opens the door slightly. We  see Longfellow. Mabel's eyes open in  surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mary Dawson here? I'm Longfellow  Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves her hand back of her, for  them to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh, yes, of course. Longfellow Deeds.  Come in. Step in, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They duck behind the sofa, CAMERA PANNING  WITH THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow enters. Mabel closes the  door behind him, watching him speculatively.  Longfellow turns to Mabel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Mabel - her sister - aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, yes - yes, of course. Her sister.  Yes, I've been her sister for a long  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other stupidly - smiling  feebly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring the camera. A hand comes in  from behind the sofa and yanks the camera  out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel and Longfellow still standing,  looking at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mary? Yes, of course. Well, I don't  know whether she's home or not. I'll  see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she turns, Babe appears in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why there she is! Of course she's home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mary. I waited in the park for  you over an hour. I thought maybe you'd  forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 181. MED. CLOSE SHOT - LONGFELLOW AND  BABE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think you could come with the  party and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't let them stop me from  seeing you. So I threw them out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. They got on my nerves, so I threw  'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that'll be in the papers tomorrow.  It will give 'em something else to laugh  at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind though. I had a lot of  fun doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to go for a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, if it isn't too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disappears, leaving Mabel and Longfellow  again staring at each other, self-consciously.  Mabel smiles, ill-at-ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice day out - er, nice night - wasn't  it? - isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, lovely. We've had a lot of nice  weather lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be a nice night to go for a  walk, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I think it'd be a swell night  to go for a walk. A nice long one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Frank, holding their breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, she looks better every time I  see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Don't worry. I won't keep  her out late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit. Mabel sighs relievedly. The  boys jump from their crouching positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank grabs his camera and both bolt  toward the door. Mabel gets there one  step ahead of them, and blocks their  path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't. Just a minute. No more  photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk slowly down the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason why I wanted to take a walk,  Mary, is 'cause I wanted to talk to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk along a foggy street, on  their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a day or so, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuing on them, as they slowly walk  around the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man ought to know where he fits in.  I just don't fit in around here. I once  had an idea I could do something with  the money, but they kept me so busy  here, I haven't had time to figure it  out. I guess I'll wait till I get back  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause. Both lost in  their own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I talk to you, Mary?  You don't have to pay any attention  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my life, I've wanted somebody to  talk to. Back in Mandrake Falls, I always  used to talk to a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, an imaginary one. I used to hike  a lot through the woods and I'd always  take this girl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with me so I could talk to her. I'd  show her my pet trees and things. Sounds  kind of silly but we had a lot of fun  doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't married 'cause I've been kinda  waiting. You know, my mother and father  were a great couple. I thought I might  have the same kind of luck. I've always  hoped that some day that imaginary girl  would turn out to be real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have arrived back at the front  steps of Babe's home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Babe. She cuts him off, her  voice shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling. Don't let anybody  hurt you again - ever. They can't anyway.  You're much too real. You go back to  Mandrake Falls. That's where you belong  - goodbye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops and turns. He walks up close  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the poem I told you about?  It's finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand goes to his breast pocket -  and then slowly is withdrawn - without  bringing out the poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to read it? It's to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He now takes the poem out. The paper  is folded. He hands it to her and she  slowly unfolds it. Just as she is about  to read Longfellow lays a hand on her  arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to say anything, Mary.  You can tell me tomorrow what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks into his eyes, but does not  respond. Then she holds the paper up  and begins reading. Longfellow watches  her anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I tramped the earth with hopeless beat  - Searching in vain for a glimpse of  you. Then heaven thrust you at my very  feet, A lovely angel - too lovely to  woo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last words come with difficulty.  Babe's eyes are slowly welling up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My dream has been answered, but my  life's just as bleak,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm handcuffed and speechless in your  presence divine -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For my heart longs to cry out, if it  only would speak,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I love you, my angel - be mine, be  mine.' "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice is choked when she finishes.  She does not look up until she refolds  the paper. He stands close to her, waiting  expectantly. Finally, she glances up.  Her cheeks are moist, and her face clouded.  Impulsively, she throws her arms around  his neck, kissing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow's arms encircle her and for  a few moments they remain in an emotional  embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to say anything now.  I'll wait till tomorrow - till I hear  from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are beset with fears. She loves  him - but knows how hopeless it all  is. She slowly starts freeing herself  from his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Babe, weeping softly, frees herself  from his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow gives a yelp of joy and leaps  down the steps. He trips over a garbage  pail and bumps into passersby, making  a racket as he zigzags down the street  and out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Babe! Stop it! What do you  mean, you're quitting! You might as  well tell me I'm quitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal  Babe near a window, peering out moodily.  Mac crosses over to her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night he proposed to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proposed to you! You mean he asked you  to marry him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cinderella Man Woos Mystery Girl! Who  is the Mysterious Girl ThatВ—"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Print one line of that, and I'll blow  your place up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Babe. Sorry. It would have made  a swell story. I just got carried away.  That's too bad. So he proposed to you,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a twist! You set out to nail him  - and heВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you haven't gone and fallen for  that mug, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places an arm tenderly around her  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to tell him the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him you're Babe Bennett? Tell him  you've been making a stooge out of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having lunch with him today. He  expects an answer. It's going to be  pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy! You can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over their shoulders, from behind, as  Mac comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll probably kick me right down the  stairs. I only hope he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put you on another job. You need  never see him again, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, as bad as that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telling him is the long shot - I'm going  to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her sympathetically. Babe  sighs resignedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was fun while it lasted, Mac.  I'll clean out my desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves him. Mac is deeply moved  by her problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Longfellow, in a buoyant mood, emerges  from his room and slides down the bannister  of the grand staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table is set for two. Two butlers putter  around. Longfellow enters full of expectant  enthusiasm. He is in his shirt sleeves.  He hovers over them, checking their  preparations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, quite all right. Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up a salt shaker and examining  it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the best you've got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those flowers are too high. Won't be  able to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a smaller bowl, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating his command as he hands the  bowl to the other butler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. A smaller bowl of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get that stuff I was telling  you about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goo. That stuff that tastes like  soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. Here it is, sir. The pate  de fois gras, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's fine. Have a lot of it  because she likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other butler returns with a small  bowl of flowers which he places in the  center of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you got the idea. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in one of the chairs and leans  forward in an imaginary conversation  with Babe - his lips move but we hear  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You're too tall. Slink lower, will  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are practically nose to nose over  the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now don't touch a thing.  Leave everything as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter! Walter! Walter, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. What is it, sir? Anything  happened3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything happened? I've got to get dressed!  I can't meet her like this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she isn't due for an hour, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour? What's an hour! You know how  time flies, Walter. My tie? Get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Very good, sir. Here it is  right here, sir. There, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While putting it on, he sings "Humoresque"  loudly and gaily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, Cobb bursts in - his  face grim:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as I suspected, wise guy! I don't  mind you making a sap out of yourself  - but you made one out of me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell the gentleman I'm not  in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Dawson, huh? Mary Dawson, my eye.  That dame took you for a sleigh ride  that New York will laugh about for years.  She's the slickest, two-timing, double-crossingВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mention of the name, Longfellow  turns for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face goes livid, as Cobb's voice  continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow has started out toward him.  In two long strides, Longfellow has  grabbed Cobb by the shirt-front, ready  to strangle him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Go ahead. Sock away, and  then try to laugh this off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his free hand, he reaches into  his coat pocket. He unrolls a newspaper.  Longfellow shifts his glance over to  the photograph in the newspaper Cobb  holds up, and slowly his grip on Cobb  relaxes. He takes the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Louise (Babe) Bennett - wins Pulitzer  Prize for reportorial job on Macklyn  love triange."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow stares long and unbelievingly  at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 208. MED. CLOSE SHOT - COBB AND LONGFELLOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the star reporter on The Mail.  Every time you opened your kisser, you  gave her another story. She's the dame  who slapped that monicker on you - "Cinderella  Man." You've been making love to a double  dose of cyanide!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow, stunned, crosses to the  bed - CAMERA PANNING WITH HIM. He slumps  down and continues staring at picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb crosses to phone and picks up receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe is at her desk. She has just finished  rummaging through her desk. Many articles  are on top. Mac is by her side. Babe  flicks the pages of a small loose-leaf  book, and hands it to Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for you , Mac. The names of  all the headwaiters in town. You can  always buy a bit of choice scandal from  them at reasonable prices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, listen Babe, I can't let you quit  now. You're not going through with this  thing, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe shakes her head with finality,  as the phone bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen 'em get in a rut like you  before - but they always come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the receiver out to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for you. In a couple weeks you'll  get the itch so bad, you'll be working  for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens and hands phone to Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face goes dead as she realizes she  is speaking to Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it you who's been writing those articles  about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why - uh - I was just leaving - I'll  be up there in a minuteВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - uh, yes, I did - but I was just  coming up to explainВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words die in her throat. She looks  dully at the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh listen, darling, wait a minute! Please!  ListenВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. His face is a dead mask,  every illusion shattered. Slowly, a  wry smile appears on his face and, rising,  he wanders around the room in deep abstraction.  Cobb and Walter watch him sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is silent a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg pardon, sir. Shall I serve the  wine with the squab, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I knew you were going to take it  so hard, I woulda kept my mouth shut.  Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As finally Longfellow speaks, without  turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pack my things, Walter. I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow emerges from his bedroom,  walking briskly toward the staircase,  immediately followed by Cobb and Walter.  Walter is loaded down with suitcases.  Longfellow is wearing coat and hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be running away like this.  What's going to happen to the Estate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the staircase, a commotion  is heard from stairs. Cobb hurries ahead  to see what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two butlers are struggling with a wild-eyed  man of middle age. They shout in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go! I wanna see him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not home, I tell you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue to struggle as Cobb reaches  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is! I just wanted to get a  look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Longfellow over Cobb's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are! I just wanted to see  what kind of a man you were!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles to thrust Cobb aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Longfellow, who has reached  the bottom of the staircase and watches  the man warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to see what a man looks  like that can spend thousands of dollars  on a party - while people around him  are hungry! The "Cinderella Man," huh?  Did you ever stop to think how many  families could have been fed on the  money you pay out to get on the front  pages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Take him out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you know what's good for you - you'll  let me get this off my chest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you feel feeding doughnuts to  a horse? Get a kick out of it, huh?  Got a big laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever think of feeding doughnuts  to human beings! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I call the police, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - that's all that's worrying you.  What do I want? A chance to feed a wife  and kids! I'm a farmer. A job! That's  what I want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A farmer, eh! You're a moocher, that's  what you are! I wouldn't believe you  or anybody else on a stack of bibles!  You're a moocher like all the rest of  them around here, so get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure - everybody's a moocher to you.  A mongrel dog eating out of a garbage  pail is a moocher to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to push him towards the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This won't do you any goodВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man shoves him away, suddenly whips  out a gun and levels it at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are, young feller. Get  over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb backs away and the man points the  gun at Longfellow, who remains staring  at him, immobilely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're about to get some more publicity,  Mr. Deeds! You're about to get on the  front page again! See how you're going  to like it this time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what good your money's going to  do when you're six feet under ground.  You never thought of that, did you?  No! All you ever thought of was pinching  pennies - you money-grabbing hick! You  never gave a thought to all of those  starving peopleВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—not knowing where their next meal was  coming from! Not able to feed their  wife and kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't go on. A sob escapes. He reaches  up and brushes away a tear with a rough  hand. It seems to bring him to his senses.  He glances down and seeing the gun in  his hand - stares at it in surprise.  He realizes what he was about to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man slumps into a chair and the  gun drops to the floor. Cobb bends quickly  and picks it up. Longfellow never moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I didn't hurt nobody. Excuse  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his head slowly and peers at  them with non-seeing eyes, then suddenly  he hides his face in his hands and sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy. You get all kinds of crazy ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't know what I was doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of it seems to come out of  him effortfully - his voice breaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Losing your farm after twenty years'  work - seeing your kids go hungry -  a game little wife saying "Everything's  going to be all right."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing there in the bread lines. It  killed me to take a handout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and do what you want with me,  mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm at the end of my rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sobs openly. While he was speaking,  Longfellow was peering into the man's  face intently. As the man finishes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the table that was all set for Babe.  The man sits, eating. He seriously bends  over his food. Longfellow sits opposite  him - his eyes glued on the man, absorbed  in profound thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take some of this home with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "LONGFELLOW DEEDS TO GIVE FORTUNE AWAY  Huge farming district to be divided  into ten acre farms - fully equipped  - at a cost of eighteen million dollars."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "THOUSANDS OF UNEMPLOYED STORM DEEDS  HOME FOR FARM DONATIONS"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mob of shouting men and women clamor  at the gates, being jostled around by  the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been transformed into an office.  Longfellow sits at one end of the room.  Clerks are at several desks. On one  side and leading out into the hall,  is a long line of men waiting to be  interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Longfellow's desk. He has a two days'  growth of beard and looks worn. Next  to him is a clerk. In front of him is  an applicant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the camera moves in on him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Dodsworth. I think you'll  qualify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this to that desk over there for  further instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man steps forward and stands in front  of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going awfully slow. We need 1100  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello . . . oh, yes. Yes. The water  development seems okay - but I don't  like the road layout yet. Come up tonight  about ten and bring the maps. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the farmer in previous sequence approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the order for the plows. We got  a good price on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. Thanks. I'll look 'em over  later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow looks up. Farmer goes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—my wife wanted me to tell you sheВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—she prays for you every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do? What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! We're not buying any bulls.  What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, fellow, bull's what I've been  selling all my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar behind his desk. In front of him  is Henry Semple and his nagging wife.  Cedar shoves a paper in front of Semple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have very little time. He's ordered  me to turn everything over to him immediately.  We have to work fast before he disposes  of every penny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See! I told you something could be done.  I knew it all the time. Sign it, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are millions involved. After all,  you have your legal rights. You're his  only living relatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Semple picks up the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your agreement with Mr. Cedar,  if we win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, my end is going to be rather  expensive. I have a lot of important  people to take care of. I have the legal  machinery all set and ready to go. I've  been working on nothing else for the  last week. You say the word, and we'll  stop this yokel dead in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the perturbed expression still  on his face, Semple reaches over to  sign the document. Simultaneously, Cedar  flicks a button on his dictagraph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, we're off! Papers all set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out who wrote those newspaper articles  and subpoena them right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, raw-boned Swede stands before  Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South Dakota - but on the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your knocking off for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not hungry. I want to get through this  work in a hurry, and then I want to  go home. What price did you get on those  trucks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. What are you trying  to do, kid? Keel over? You haven't been  out of this house in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I will have a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind waiting a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, sure. If you like to have  a sandwich, I can give you one, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brings out two huge sandwiches, and  hands one to Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thank you. Never mind, Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it, and he and the Swede silently  eat. Longfellow looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Swede smiles. Longfellow nibbles  his sandwich, then glances around the  room. His gaze rests on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the long line of applicants waiting  for an audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb! Get lunch for the rest of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? There must be 2000 of them out  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that doesn't make 'em any less  hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Longfellow glances over at  the line, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the line there is a slight  scuffle, as a man is being pushed forward  by some others. He mumbles a protest,  tries to get back into position, but  the men push him forward again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, say something. Say something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 238. MED. CLOSE SHOT - MEN IN LINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man finally is resigned, and stands  shifting, ill-at-ease, his head hanging  bashfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, the boys here wanted me to  say a little something. They just wanted  me to say thatВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they wanted me to say thatВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think you're swell - and that's no  baloney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spokesman apparently has not finished  yet. Directly behind the line, three  officious-looking men have made their  appearance and wait for him to conclude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a chance, fellas. We're all  down and out - but when a fellow like  you comes along, kinda gives us a little  hope - and they just wanted me to sayВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as far as he gets - as the three  strangers break their way through the  line and approach Longfellow's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a warrant to take you into  custody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warrant for your arrest. You'll have  to come along with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up? What do you mugs want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing, buddy. All I know  is the Sheriff gives me an insanity  warrant to execute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn to Charlie, who comes  forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The complainant is a relative of the  late Martin Semple. The charges are  that Mr. Deeds is insane and incapable  of handling the Estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, somebody got panic-stricken about  his giving his dough away, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going to take  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, that's only temporary. A  hearing will follow immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. Just because I want to  give this money to people who need it,  they think I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's marvelous. That makes everything  complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Not so fast. We're going  to get a lawyer. I'll call Cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I'm from Mr. Cedar's  office. He represents the complainant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow glances up at him and smiles  bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's go. We're wasting a lot  of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to one side of Longfellow, and  his partner to the other. They take  Longfellow by the arms. He glances down  casually and, suddenly, violently pushes  the deputies away from him. They are  thrown backward; their eyes widen in  surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll go. But get your hands  off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow starts to walk forward, accompanied  by Cobb - and the two deputies and Charlie  fall in behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be intercut with above scene. They  stare, petrified, and mumble to each  other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the farmers and other applicants.  The line has fallen out and they stand  in a bunch, staring pathetically and  hopelessly at the departing group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who stands in f.g. of bunch. What is  taking place has slowly penetrated his  befuddled brain. The disappointment  he feared is here. His body imperceptibly  sags, his eyes dim - all hope having  gone out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guard sits at a desk near a door,  talking on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, most everybody in town has been  here to see him. Yes, sir. I won't.  GoodbyeВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe rounds the corner quickly, heading  for the door. The guard hurriedly hangs  up and stands to block her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please! I've got to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, sister, for the fourteenth  and last time he don't want to see nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just give him my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, toots, just between us, there  ain't a thing in the world the matter  with that guy till I mention your name,  then he goes haywire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is seated by the far wall,  peering moodily out the window. Cobb  paces about. Suddenly, he wheels on  Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do - just sit  back and let them railroad you? It's  as pretty a frameup as ever hit this  rotten town! If you'd just let me get  you a lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow pays no attention to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't walk into that courtroom without  being ready to protect yourself in the  clinches. Cedar's too smart. With the  array of talent he's got lined up against  you - you're cooked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is still unresponsive. Cobb  thinks a moment, watching him studiously;  then pleading tenderly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, pal - I know just how you feel.  A blonde in Syracuse put me through  the same paces. I came out with a sour  puss - but full of fight. Come on, you  don't want to lay down now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what's happening? They're  trying to prove that you're nuts! If  they win the case, they'll shove you  in the bughouse. The moment they accuse  you of it, they have you half licked.  You've got to fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow disregards him and Cobb sighs,  resignedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard is reading his paper. Babe  is still waiting, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, sit down, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cobb comes out. The guard gets up  to check the door is locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb, in a troubled frame of mind, doesn't  respond and starts down corridor - CAMERA  TRUCKS WITH HIM. Babe catches up with  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb doesn't stop. Babe grabs his arm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to see him! I've got to talk  to him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you done enough damage already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's got to help him! He hasn't  got a chance against Cedar. Look, I've  been all over town talking to everybody.  I've got Mac all lined up - and the  paper's behind him. And I can get him  Livingston, too. With a lawyer like  Livingston, he's got a fighting chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time. He doesn't  want any lawyers. He's sunk so low,  he doesn't want help from anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take a bow for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As swell a guy as ever hit this town,  and you crucified him! For a couple  of stinking headlines! You've done your  bit - now stay out of his way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits abruptly, leaving Babe staring  despairingly at his disappearing back,  his brutal diatribe ringing harshly  in her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semple Heir Charged With Incompetency!  'Should Be Confined To An Institution,'  Declares Cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Farmers Aroused At Efforts to Balk  Their Benefactor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Police Surround Courthouse In Anticipation  Of Outbreak."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of an unruly mob - being jostled by  the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor is jammed with curious  public endeavoring to gain entrance.  Perspiring police fight to keep them  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is practically full. The few empty  seats are being quickly filled. People  stumble over each other to find a seat.  The judge is not yet at his bench. There  is a general chatter of excitement and  anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the spectators Babe sits beside  Mac. She stares, expression-less. Mac  glances at her sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring the farmer who broke into  Longfellow's house. Near him is the  Swede we saw - and others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar and his assistants arrange their  papers. Two dignified gentlemen, psychiatrists,  await action, arms folded. Near them  is Henry Semple, the complainant, his  nose twitching nervously. By his side  is his wife, sparkling expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At which sit a dozen newspaper reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a side door Longfellow enters,  accompanied by his guard. Immediately  the place is astir. As he advances to  a chair in front of a tableВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Necks crane for a glimpse. Whispered  conversations take place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks guilty, nose twitching more  violently than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe sits up, her eyes riveted on Longfellow.  Impulsively she starts to rise, but  Mac puts a restraining hand on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow turns neither to left nor  right. He is slumped low in his chair,  staring solemnly into space. Cobb breaks  into scene and sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar just sent for me. Wants to make  a settlement. Here's your chance to  get out of the whole mess. What do you  say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets no response from Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a stir in the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bailiff calls out as the Judge proceeds  to his bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, please! The Supreme Court of  the State of New York, County of New  York, is now in session, the Honorable  John May, Judge, presiding. Be seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court wishes to warn those present  that it will tolerate no disturbances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regarding the sanity hearing of Longfellow  Deeds, are you represented by counsel,  Mr. Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost imperceptibly, Longfellow shakes  his head no. The Judge looks troubled.  There is a stir in the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that you have no counsel,  Mr. Deeds. In fact, that you have no  intention of defending any of these  charges. Now, if you wish to change  your mind, the hearing can be postponed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting no response from Longfellow,  the Judge shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—and in the interests of my client,  the only other living relative of the  late Martin W. Semple, we cannot permit  a fortune so huge to be dissipated by  a person whose incompetency and abnormality  we shall prove beyond any reasonable  doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have before me a series of articles  written by a newspaper woman who was  an eye-witness to his conduct ever since  he came to New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS on Babe and Mac. Cedar's  voice goes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tells how, in the midst of a normal  conversation, he would suddenly begin  playing his tuba. She tells of his attacks  upon several of our eminent writers  - for no apparent reason. In fact, there  are many instances not recorded in these  articles in which Mr. Deeds satisfied  an unnatural desire to smash people  up without provocation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, myself, unable to keep pace with  his mental quirks, and constantly fearful  of assault, turned down an opportunity  to represent him as his attorney. This  newspaper woman, whom we have subpoenaed  to testify, tells how he tied up traffic  for an hour feeding doughnuts to a poor  horse. And by his own statement, waiting  for that horse to ask for a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is laughter in the courtroom -  which quickly subsides when the Judge  pounds his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have photographs to substantiate  this little episode, and other photographs  showing Mr. Deeds jumping upon a fire  engine. This scarcely sounds like the  action of a man in whom the disposition  of twenty million dollars may safely  be entrusted. This writer of these articles  - a woman whose intelligence and integrity  in the newspaper world is unquestioned  - held him in such contempt that she  quite aptly named him "The Cinderella  Man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have witnesses here from Mandrake  Falls, his own home town, who will tell  of his conduct throughout his lifetime,  proving that his derangement is neither  recent nor a temporary one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow's interest is only slightly  aroused. He lifts his eyes in a casual  glance around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have others who will tell of his  unusual behavior when he invited the  great leaders of the musical world to  his home, and then proceeded to forcibly  eject them. Only recently when he was  in the County Hospital for observation,  he not only refused to be examined by  these gentlemen, the state psychiatrists,  but he actually made a violent attack  upon them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cedar continues talking, CAMERA PULLS  BACK to WIDER SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In these times, with the country incapacitated  by economic ailments, and endangered  with an undercurrent of social unrest,  the promulgation of such a weird, fantastic  and impractical plan as contemplated  by the defendant, is capable of fomenting  a disturbance from which the country  may not soon recover. It is our duty  to stop it! Our government is fully  aware of its difficulties and can pull  itself out of its economic rut without  the assistance of Mr. Deeds, or any  other crackpot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of farmers, the Swede and others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His attempted action must therefore  be attributed to a diseased mind afflicted  with hallucinations of grandeur, and  obsessed with an insane desire to become  a public benefactor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 275. CLOSE SHOT AT FRONT OF COURTROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, at this time, we would like  to call our first witness: Miss Louise  - Babe - Bennett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a mild stir, and all wait expectantly  for Babe to appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe, eyes on Longfellow, slowly walks  to the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his face averted and doesn't  look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe continues to rivet her eyes on  Longfellow, as she is sworn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you solemnly swear the testimony  you may give before this court to be  the truth, the whole truth and nothing  but the truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 279. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT WITNESS STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cedar steps up to question Babe.  Judge in f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennett, are you employed by the  Morning Mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer. Babe continues to  stare off at Longfellow, hoping he will  look up. Cedar speaks to her again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must ask you to direct your attention  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Babe's attention remains focused  on Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole hearing's ridiculous! That  man's no more insane than you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suddenness of her outbreak is startling.  The Judge pounds his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obviously a frameup! They're trying  to railroad this man for the money they  can get out of him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge pounds his gavel throughout  her speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young lady, another outburst like that  and I shall hold you in contempt! We're  not interested in your opinion of the  merits of this case. You're here to  testify. Sit down and answer the questions.  Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Honor. Are you employed  by the Morning Mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar's eyes widen in surprise. There  is a light stir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are under oath, Miss Bennett. I  ask you again - are you employed by  the Morning Mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, prior to that time - were you  employed by the Morning Mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 282. CLOSE SHOT AT WITNESS STAND - BABE  AND CEDAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you given an assignment to follow  the activities of Longfellow Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you subsequently write a series  of articles about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you present when all these things  took place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're colored! Just to make him look  silly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't all! I'd like to explainВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all, Miss Bennett. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bailiff takes Babe by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I'd like to submit these  articles as evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe struggles away from the bailiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of hearing is this? What are  you trying to do - persecute the man?  He's not defending himself. Somebody's  got to do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout her tirade, the Judge has  been angrily pounding his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a right to be heard! I've attended  dozens of cases like this. They're usually  conducted without any formality at all.  Anybody can be heard! My opinion is  as good as these quack psychiatrists.  I know him better than they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bennett, if you have quite finished,  I should like to inform you that one  more utterance from you and I shall  place you under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm willing to hear anything anyone  has to say - but I insist on it being  done in an orderly fashion. When you  have learned to show some respect for  this court, you may return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until then, you'd better go back to  your seat and calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Babe is led away, there is another  courtroom stir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Babe is out of sight, the Judge  turns to Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, have you anything to say  in defense of these articles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow shakes his head. Cobb glances  to him helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark these Exhibit A for the plaintiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she sits down beside Mac - who places  an affectionate arm around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two old ladies are being led to the  witness stand. Their eyelids flutter  excitedly as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up, sees the old ladies and  smiles at them friendily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 291. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT JUDGE'S BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against the drone of the clerk, who  swears witnesses in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Falkner sisters are rather timid,  Your Honor, and wish to be together.  If the court pleases, I will only have  one of them testify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! Let's get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 292. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT WITNESS STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cedar addresses one of the old ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Falkner. This is my sister, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll direct my questions to you, Miss  Jane. You can answer for both. Do you  know the defendant, Mr. Longfellow Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two old ladies look at each other,  then in the direction in which Cedar  points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, yes - of course we know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you known him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane turns to her sister, and they whisper  to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Elsie Taggart was the midwife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, that's fine. Do you see him  very often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two old ladies have their whispered  conference again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you just answer, Miss Jane.  Now, will you tell the Court what everybody  at home thinks of Longfellow Deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two old ladies consult each other  once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that you said he was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's a rather strange word to  use, Miss Jane. Can you tell the court  exactly what it means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the two ladies go into a huddle:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one of them speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I can explain, Your Honor. The  word pixilated is an early American  expression - derived from the word 'pixies,'  meaning elves. They would say, 'The  pixies had got him,' as we nowadays  would say a man is 'balmy.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge nods his understanding. The  Falkner sisters nod in pleasant agreement.  Cedar sighs victoriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tell me, why does everyone think  he's - uh - pixilated? Does he do peculiar  things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks in the rain, without his hat,  and talks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recently he gave Chuck Dillon a thumping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For no reason, I guess. He always does  it. We always run into the house when  we see him coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never can tell what he's going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes - he's pixilated all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar beams. The old ladies leave to  resume their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kept hollering: "Back to Nature!  Back to Nature!" I thought they looked  harmless enough so I took them home.  I never thought he was cracked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a waiter. He kept pressing me to  point out the celebrities, and so help  me Hannah I'm coming out of the kitchen  a coupla minutes later and there he  is moppin' up the floors with them.  I never figured he was a guy looking  for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He threw us out bodily! But bodily!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 299. MED. CLOSE SHOT IN WITNESS STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of one of the bodyguards on witness  stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We was hired as his bodyguard, see?  Well, the first crack out of the box,  he throws us in a room and locks the  door, see? Now, if a thing like that  gets around in our profession, we'd  get the bird - see? So I says to my  partner, "Let's quit this guy, he's  nuts!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very fond of Clara, sir. She's a  nice 'orse. And when this bloke 'ere  started feedin' 'er doughnuts, I yelled  down to him, "Mind what you're doin'  down there! Mind what you're doing'!"  Of course I wouldn't mind, sir, but  Clara won't eat nothin' but doughnuts,  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of one of the photographers (Bob) and  enlarged photographs of Longfellow's  antics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I wish to call your attention  to these exhibits. Mr. Davis, do you  recognize these reproductions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, they're good enlargements. Where'd  you have them made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make the originals of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I took the originals. Taking pictures  is my business. I photograph a lot of  nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, Your Honor, if the court pleases,  I shall call upon Dr. Emil Von Holler,  if he will be good enough to give us  his opinion. Dr. Von Holler, as you  know, is the eminent Austrian psychiatrist  - probably the greatest authority on  the subject in the world. At present  he is in this country on a lecture tour,  and has graciously volunteered his services.  Dr. Von Holler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the clerk finishes swearing Dr. Von  Holler in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you solemnly swear the testimony  you are about to give in the cause now  pending before this court shall be the  truth, the whole truth and nothing but  the truth, so help you God? State your  right name, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 303. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT WITNESS STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Dr. Von Holler, will you kindly  tell the court what your opinion is  on this case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is purely a case of manic depression.  In cases of this kind, patients sometimes  go on for years before being detected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to one of the psychiatrists,  sitting with the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember, Dr. Fosdick, in my last  book there are some very fine examples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially, the one of the young nobleman,  you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Yes, of course Dr. Von Holler.  Very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reminds me very much of this one.  Nicht wahr?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes so long to detect themВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—because their mood changes so often  and so quickly. Now, Your Honor, may  I show you? May I use the chart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to a blackboard. There are  chalk marks on it. A straight line runs  diagonally across the center. Other  lines run zig-zag over and below this  center line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below here, they are extremely depressed,  melancholy, impossible to live with,  and often become violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this mood the manic depressive  might gradually change until they reach  this state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is lucidity. Here they are perfectly  normal. As normal as you or IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—assuming, of course, that we are normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the mood changes again untilВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—they reach this state, a state of highest  exaltation. Here everything is fine.  Here the world is beautiful. Here they  are so elated - how do you express it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—they would give you the shirt off their  backs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Von Holler, how would you say that  applied to Mr. Deeds's case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he was here, on top of the wave,  he felt nothing but kindliness and warmth  toward his fellow-men. He wanted them  around him. So he decided he would give  a big reception. But in the meantime,  his mood has changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now at the bottom of the wave  - depressed - melancholy. So, when his  guests arrive, he throws them out. They  are now his imaginary enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other instances of high elation are  when he plays his tuba, when he writes  his poetry, when he chases fire engines  in his desire to help humanity. This  is contrasted with his present mood,  which is so low that even the instinct  for self-preservation is lacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
