dialogues.text: Oh, the man is verrukt. Your Honor,  this is decidedly a case of a manic  depressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Von Holler returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a shifting of bodies, and a  renewed interest, as they wait for the  next move. The Judge and his own two  experts go into an inaudible huddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow is slumped in his seat, head  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, what're you going to do? Let  them get away with it? They got you  cooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an expectant stir in the courtroom  among the spectators and rows of reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 308. MED. CLOSE SHOT - THE JUDGE AND  HIS EXHIBITS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge comes out of his huddle and glances  at Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, before the court arrives  at a decision, isn't there anything  you wish to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on - don't be a sap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge watches him a few moments,  hesitatingly, and then turns to his  experts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 311. CLOSE SHOT - CEDAR AND HIS CLIENTS,  ASSISTANTS ETC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the Swede, the farmer, and others.  Their faces show their resentment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge emerges from his consultation  with his experts and addresses Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, in view of the extensive  testimony and your continued silence  and upon recommendation of the doctors,  the Court considers it advisable for  your own safety that you be committed  to an institution as prescribed by law.  You need medical attention, Mr. Deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the air is rent with the shrill  voice of Babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! No! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are startled and look up. Babe runs  right to the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do it! You've got to make  him talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns directly to Longfellow - leaning  over close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, darling, please. I know everything  I've done. I know how horrible I've  been. No matter what happens, if you  never see me again, do this for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I could speak! You said I could  have my say if I were rational. I'm  rational. Please, let me take the witness  chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must be made to defend himself before  you arrive at a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe goes up to the witness stand and  sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, what she is saying has no  bearing on the case. I object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why he won't defend himself!  That has a bearing on the case, hasn't  it? He's been hurt! He's been hurt by  everybody's he met since he came here,  principally by me. He's been the victim  of every conniving crook in town. The  newspapers pounced on him - made him  a target for their feeble humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was smarter than the rest of them!  I got closer to him so I could laugh  louder. Why shouldn't he keep quiet?  Every time he said anything it was twisted  around to sound imbecilic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can thank me for it! I handed the  gang a grand laugh. This is a fitting  climax to my sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Your Honor - this is preposterous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge waves him down with a dismissing  gesture of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly I wrote those articles. I  was going to get a raise - and a month's  vacation! But I stopped writing them  when I found out what he was all about!  When I realized how real he was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could never fit in with our distorted  viewpoint because he's honest and sincere  - and good. If that man is crazy, Your  Honor, the rest of us belong in straight-jackets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, this is absurd. The woman's  obviously in love with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you are in love with him, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be intercut during her speech. At  first he merely glances up at her speculatively.  Finally, he begins to show some interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, her testimony is of no value.  Why shouldn't she defend him? It's a  tribute to American womanhood - the  instinct to protect the weak. I'm not  saying that nobody likes the boy. I  cherish a fond affection for him myself.  But that doesn't mean to sayВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of his speech, Mac - the  editor - appears at his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the windbag here gets through,  Your Honor, I'd like to verify what  Miss Bennett said. I'm her editor. When  she quit her job, she told me what a  swell fellow this man was. And anything  Babe Bennett says is okay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have anything to say, you will  take the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already said it, Your Honor. I  just thought I'd like to get my two  cents in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts to go, CAMERA PANNING WITH  HIM, he passes Longfellow. He nudges  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a sucker, pal. Stand up and  speak your piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I've got a couple of cents  I'd like to put inВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been with this man ever since he  came to New YorkВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward the Judge. He pounds  his gavel, interrupting Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down! There will be no further interruptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost simultaneously with the Judge's  speech, the farmer, somewhere in the  audience, rises to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward audience. As the farmer  finishes, a dozen others are on their  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! What about us, Mr. Deeds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to leave us out in  the cold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're trying to frame you, Mr. Deeds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The turmoil is general, with bailiffs  running to quiet them. The Judge pounding  his gavel, incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the interest of Mr. Deeds, I have  tolerated a great deal of informality.  But if there is one more outburst, I  shall have the courtroom cleared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to get in my two cents' worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general stir of excitement  - and whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clients look up at Cedar, concerned.  Cedar comforts them with a confident  grimace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To include Longfellow, Judge, and others  around them. Longfellow hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know where to begin. There's  been so many things said about me that  IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About my playing the tuba. Seems like  a lot of fuss has been made about that.  If a man's crazy just 'cause he plays  the tuba, then somebody better look  into it, 'cause there are a lot of tuba  players running around loose. Of course,  I don't see any harm in it. I play mine  whenever I want to concentrate. That  may sound funny to some people - but  everybody does something silly when  they're thinking. For instance, the  Judge here is an O-filler . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An O-filler. You fill in all the spaces  in the O's, with your pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge looks down at a paper in front  of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of some sort. All the O's and P's and  R's have the white spaces pencilled  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks up from the document. He  is a trifle self-conscious. Laughter  comes from the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may make you look a little crazy,  Your Honor, just sitting around filling  in O's - but I don't see anything wrong  'cause that helps you to think. Other  people are doodlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a name we made up back home for  people who make foolish designs on paper  when they're thinking. It's called doodling.  Almost everybody's a doodler. Did you  ever see a scratch pad in a telephone  booth? People draw the most idiotic  pictures when they're thinking. Dr.  Von Holler, here, could probably think  up a long name for it, because he doodles  all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Von Holler, who is in the middle  of some doodling, flinches. A roar of  laughter comes from the spectators.  Longfellow reaches over to where Dr.  Von Holler sits and picks up a piece  of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a piece of paper he was scribbling  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't figure it out. One minute it  looks like a chimpanzee - and the next  minute it looks like a picture of Mr.  Cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge, with a serious mien, takes  the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Von Holler is somewhat uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks kind of stupid, doesn't it, Your  Honor? But I guess that's all right  if Dr. Von Holler has to doodle to help  him think. That's his business. Everybody  does something different. Some people  areВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Mr. Semple over there is a nose-twitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 333. CLOSE SHOT - SEMPLE AND HIS WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up, startled, his nose twitching  more violently than ever. The courtroom  rocks with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife, in her nervousness, pulls  at her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the lady next to him is a knuckle-cracker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Semple quickly drops her hands  in her lap, as the courtroom again fills  with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings a key-ring around his forefinger.  Suddenly he realizes Longfellow might  get to him, and he hastily palms the  keys and shoves them in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One is leaning forward, listening intently  - biting the end of his pencil. The  one next to him nudges him and silently  points to the pencil in his mouth. The  reporter gets the idea and, smiling  sheepishly, yanks it out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 336. MED. CLOSE SHOT - FRONT OF COURTROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you see, everybody does silly things  to help them think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd echoes him with shouts and  laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glares off scene at Mac, reprimandingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is amused at the embarassment Longfellow  has caused them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 340. CLOSE SHOT - CEDAR AND HIS CLIENTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 341. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT WITNESS STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow in chair - Judge at bench,  b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, do you recall forcibly ejecting  people from your home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Yes. About my throwing those  people out of my house. Mrs. Pomponi  told the truth. I did throw them out  because I didn't want the party in the  first place. I didn't invite anybody.  Mrs. Pomponi did all that. They just  came to see what kind of a freak the  "Cinderella Man" was. I don't know how  people like that are supposed to act,  Your Honor, but if that Pomponi woman  is an example, I'll stick to simple  folks. She just came in, talked my ear  off, and took charge of everything.  If I were a friend of hers, I'd have  her examined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Longfellow. Cedar, who cannot  stand it any longer, jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, this is becoming farcical.  I demand that Mr. Deeds dispense with  side remarks and confine himself to  facts! Let him explain his wanderings  around the streets in underclothes,  his feeding doughnuts to horses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cedar's right. Those things do look  kind of bad, don't they? But to tell  the truth, Your Honor, I don't remember  them. I guess they happened, all right,  because I don't think a policeman would  lie about a thing like that, but I was  drunk. It was the first time I was ever  drunk in my life. It's probably happened  to you, some time. I mean, when you  were younger, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge clears his throat in embarrassment.  Several women giggle. The Judge sternly  pounds his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's likely to happen to anybody. Just  the other morning I read in the paper  about Mr. Cedar's own son - about how  he got drunk and insisted on driving  a taxi-cab, while the driver sat inside.  Isn't that so, Mr. Cedar? Isn't that  so , Mr. Cedar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes have turned to Cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are beginning to blaze angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now about the Falkner sisters. That's  kind of funny. I mean about Mr. Cedar  going all the way to Mandrake Falls  to bring them here. Do you mind if I  talk to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow turns. Everybody stretches  to get a better look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, who owns the house you live in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls consult with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we don't pay any rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, no! We never pay rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Jane, a little while ago you said  I was pixilated. Do you still think  so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you've always been pixilated, Longfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. I guess maybe I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tell me something, Jane. Who else  in Mandrake Falls is pixilated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane turns to her sister and this time  they go into a prolonged huddle. It  is apparently a difficult thing to figure  out. Finally they come out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, everybody in Mandrake Falls in  pixilated - except us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an outburst of laughter which  the Judge quickly quells with his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, just one more question. Do you  see the Judge here? He's a nice man,  isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is more laughter. More pounding  of the judiciary gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels his case slowly crumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can scarcely conceal her elation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, you haven't yet touched upon  a most important thing. This rather  fantastic idea of yours to want to give  away your entire fortune. It is, to  say the least, most uncommon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I was getting to that, Your  Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES TO CLOSER SHOT, featuring  Longfellow and Judge, as former continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you were living in a small town  and getting along fine, and suddenly  somebody dropped $20,000,000 in your  lap. Supposing you discovered that all  that money was messing up your life,  was bringing a lot of vultures around  your neck, and making you lose faith  in everybody. You'd be a little worried,  wouldn't you? You'd feel that you had  a hot potato in your hand, and you'd  want to drop it. I guess Dr. Von Holler  would say you were riding onВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—those bottom waves, 'cause you wanted  to drop something that was burning your  fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this man is permitted to carry out  his plan, repercussions will be felt  that will rock the foundations of our  entire governmental system!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge has pounded him into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 355. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT WITNESS STAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I don't know what Mr. Cedar's  raving about. From what I can see, no  matter what system of government we  have, there will always be leaders and  always be followers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farmers in audience, as Longfellow's  voice continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like the road out in front of my  house. It's on a steep hill. Every day  I watch the cars climbing up. Some go  lickety-split up that hill on highВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—some have to shift into second - and  some sputter and shake and slip back  to the bottom again. Same cars - same  gasoline - yet some make it and some  don't. And I say the fellows who can  make the hill on high should stop once  in a while and help those who can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I'm trying to do with this  money. Help the fellows who can't make  the hill on high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Mr. Cedar expect me to do  with it? Give it to him - and a lot  of other people who don't need it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind, Your Honor, I'll  ride on those top waves for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, all you fellows out there! All  those who applied for a farm, stand  up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing most of the audience struggling  to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See all those fellows? They're the ones  I'm trying to help. They need it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cedar and that Mr. Semple don't  need anything. They've got plenty! It's  like I'm out in a big boat and I see  one fellow in a rowboat who's tired  of rowing and wants a free ride - and  another fellow who's drowning. Who would  you expect me to rescue? Mr. Cedar,  who just got tired of rowing and wants  a free ride? Or those men out there  who are drowning? Any ten-year-old child  will give you the answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, fellows. Thank you. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, my plan is very simple. I was going  to give each family ten acres - a horse,  a cow and some seed. And if they work  the farm for three years, it's theirs.  Now, if that's crazy, maybe I ought  to be sent to an institution. But I  don't think it is. And what's more,  Mr. Cedar doesn't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just before the hearing started, he  offered to call the whole thing off  if I made a settlement with him. So  you see, he wouldn't think I was crazy  if he got paid off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps to his feet, highly incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds is drawing on his warped imagination!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he listens to Cedar, watching him  antagonistically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never heard anything so colossally  stupid in my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To include Longfellow, Cedar and Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an insult to our intelligence to  sit here and listen to his childish  ravings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout his speech the Judge has  been pounding his gavel. Longfellow  has his eyes levelled off on Cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will please permit Mr. Deeds to  finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar, grumblingly, remains standing.  Judge asks Longfellow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. There's just one more thing I'd  like to get off my chest before I finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises to his feet, takes one step  forward, and clouts Cedar flush on the  jaw. As Cedar falls into the arms of  an associate, pandemonium breaks loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order! Order! Order in the court!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge pounds his gavel. There are  cries of approval from the spectators.  In the midst of the commotionВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing spectators, waiting breathlessly  for a decision. All eyes are on the  Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge holds a whispered conversation  with his experts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances furtively at Babe, off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning forward. Their entire future  hangs in the balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge comes out of the huddle; his  face is very stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remain seated and come to order. The  Court is again in session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the Court announces its decision,  I want to warn all who are here that  the police have orders to arrest anyone  creating a disturbance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Babe - Cobb - Longfellow - Mac -  the farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mouth curls up in a contented grimace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are upon the Judge, who clears  his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deeds, there has been a great deal  of damaging testimony against you. Your  behavior, to say the least, has been  most strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An audible gasp is heard from audience.  Judge goes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in the opinion of the Court, you  are not only sane, but you are the sanest  man that ever walked into this courtroom.  Case dismissed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shout that greets this is tumultuous.  The Judge smiles warmly, and clasps  Longfellow's hand. Immediately, Longfellow  is surrounded by a crowd of people who  come running down the aisles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit, stunned, disappointed. Mrs.  Semple turns to her husband and slaps  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I knew it! I knew it! You, youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cedar disgustedly pushes him in the  face, aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles ecstatically, too excited  to move. Suddenly she rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Babe tries to get to Longfellow,  but finds herself on the fringe of a  jubilant crowd in the center of which  is Longfellow. She tries to break through,  but finds it impossible. Desperately,  she jumps on a chair and tries frantically  to get a glimpse of him. At that moment,  several farmers have lifted Longfellow  on their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As jubilantly, Longfellow is carried  out on the shoulders of the excited  crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Babe frantically tries to reach Longfellow,  but is jostled aside. The parade envelops  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shouting mob is heading for the  door at end of courtroom. Everyone crowds  forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty - except for the Falkner sisters,  still whispering to each other, and  Babe, sitting helpless and forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are filled. Dismally she starts  forward. We hear a rising commotion  from the outside, at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longfellow running toward camera with  the mob, shouting, back of him. He reaches  courtroom, slams the doors shut behind  him. Babe, attracted by the noise, looks  up. He runs toward her, and swoops her  up in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him over and over again.  He looks around and over his shoulder  at the mob, a little dazed. Finally,  he notices her effort, and gives her  one passionately back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that is heard is the cheering of  the crowd outside and the Columbia music.
